name: transport, freight train, steam | transport, freight train | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5503/documentation

The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle of a steam freight train in China. Coal use per tkm estimated from energy content in diesel consumed in diesel locomotives and a factor 6 lower efficiency for steam locomotives compared to diesel locomotives. Emissions are based on the dataset "hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant" and 24 MJ/kg LHV. However, emissions to air but CO2, NOx, N2O and CH4 have been arbitrarily increased by a factor of 2 per MJ, CO by a factor of 5, particles by a factor of 10, whereas ashes have been decreased by a factor of 2 compared to small coal mine power plants. This dataset should not be used for comparisons of locomotive types nor of transport means across different countries but only when transport is not a major contributor to total environmental burdens of a process or product being analyzed.

The dataset starts with the production of a locomotive.

The dataset ends with the service of transporting 1 ton over a distance of 1 km by a freight train. The dataset includes the production and the maintenance of the locomotive and the goods wagon, the construction of the railway track and the energy use and operation emissions of a freight trains using steam. The data of the energy use and operation emissions are based on "transport, freight train, diesel" dataset for RER adapting coal as fuel.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: RER model and operation model with own estimation for coal consumption & emissions per tkm. The 2004 China official statistics on the number of locomotives in operation in all railway Companies (national and local) give the shares 69.7%, 28.7% and 1.5% for diesel, electricity and steam , respectively. Coal for steam locomotives has a presumably lower ash content (say approximately 25% of coal weight) compared with coal for small coal mine plants (up to 50% of coal weight (Dones et al. 2003)), the retention efficiency is likely lower. Considering also that these locomotives are used mostly within Coal Bureaus, therefore in already highly polluted areas, and that pictures of some steam locomotive show dark and abundant plumes, the PM emission is likely high. Due to the assumptions on ash content, the disposal of ashes has been halved for the locomotive compared to small plants.;References:;Spielmann M., Kägi T., Stadler P. and Tietje O. (2004) Life cycle inventoriesof transport services. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 14. UNS, ETH-Zurich,Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, CH, retrieved from:www.ecoinvent.ch.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The dataset transport of coal by train in China is based on “transport, freight train (RER)” but instead of “transport, freight train (RER)” the input is defined to reflect the use of steam locomotives in the coal industry and in China in general. Demand factors of various transport components (as described in the previous sections) required to fulfill the functional unit of one tkm fright transport are presented. In order to account for the fact that the same rail tracks are used for both passenger and goods transportation are applied allocation factors.

flow.name: transport, freight train
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. The steam locomotive dataset is modelled in first approximation by assuming a factor of 4 in fuel (equivalent) utilization compared with a diesel locomotive, based on consideration of likely actual efficiencies (mix of first generation steam locomotives with typical drawbar thermal efficiency of approximately 7% and some second generation with superheating with efficiency up to 15%). Further correction has been applied using the factor 2.67. Energy use and operations emissions

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Coal for steam locomotives has a presumably lower ash content (say approximately 25% of coal weight) compared with coal for small coal mine plants (up to 50% of coal weight (Dones et al. 2003)), the retention efficiency is likely lower. Considering also that these locomotives are used mostly within Coal Bureaus, therefore in already highly polluted areas, and that pictures of some steam locomotive show dark and abundant plumes, the PM emission is likely high. Due to the assumptions on ash content, the disposal of ashes has been halved for the locomotive compared to small plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants.
